newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore premier sees slowdown for 3-6 months.
newsitem.headline: Singapore premier sees slowdown for 3-6 months.

text.p: Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said on Sunday he was unsure how long the current economic slowdown in the city-state would last but thought it might continue for three to six months.
Goh also said he feared the slowdown in the retail sector might last longer than the slump in the key electronics sector.
On August 12, Singapore announced a sharp decline in economic growth for the second quarter to seven percent from 10.9 percent in the same period a year ago.
Officials said the slowdown was largely due to a slump in its key electronics industry, which accounts for around half the country's industrial output and almost 60 percent of its non-oil exports.

Goh told a news conference he was cautiously optimistic over the prospects for the economy but was unsure how long the slowdown would continue. "It is difficult to say how long it will last ... Three months, six months, that is possible."
"The downturn is felt in the electronics industry, which of course then would have some influence on maybe the financial sector," Goh said.
"The downturn has come very suddenly and more sharply than people expected. We are dealing with a very volatile industry."
"My worry, of course, is over the retail sector. For the retail sector we are undergoing a restructuring change," he said.
"We would expect the retail sector to be rather slow moving for quite some time. I think that will last longer than the slowdown in the electronics industry."
Goh said part of the reason for the current "shaking-out" in Singapore's retail sector was that shops were spreading across the island and were no longer concentrated in just a few areas.
Retailers also faced the challenge of Singaporeans shopping outside the country because of the high value of the Singapore dollar, he said.
"Singaporeas now buy quite a bit from outside the country: Hong Kong, London, Malaysia because of the strong dollar," he said. ($1 = S$1.41) -- Singapore newsroom (65 8703199)
